profile: Processed Foods: Types, Risks, and Evidence

examples: Candies, chocolate bars, packaged desserts, pastries
Sugary cereals (e.g., Frosted Flakes, Cocoa Pops, Lucky Charms)
Fast food: burgers, nuggets, hot dogs, pizza
Processed meats: sausages, bacon, deli meats, pepperoni
Instant/ready meals: instant noodles, frozen pizzas, microwavable meals
Sweetened beverages: soda, energy drinks, sweetened juices
Other snacks: flavored popcorn, granola bars, crackers

effects: Cause blood sugar spikes and crashes → fatigue, cravings, poor recovery
Excess sugar increases fat storage, especially visceral fat
Linked to insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes
evidence: Malik et al. (2010). High sugar intake increases risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Diabetes Care.

effects: Excess sodium increases high blood pressure and cardiovascular strain
In athletes: can cause water retention and poor recovery
evidence: Mozaffarian et al. (2014). High sodium diets increase hypertension and CVD risk. NEJM.

effects: Increase LDL cholesterol, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease risk
Suppress testosterone and impair recovery when overconsumed
evidence: Mozaffarian et al. (2006). Trans fats linked to higher cardiovascular mortality. NEJM.

effects: Energy-dense, nutrient-poor → deficiencies in vitamins, minerals, fiber
Low satiety → overeating and weight gain
evidence: Hall et al. (2019). Ultra-processed foods promote excess calorie intake. Cell Metabolism.

effects: Emulsifiers, colorings, artificial sweeteners can alter gut microbiome
Gut imbalance linked to inflammation, obesity, metabolic dysfunction
evidence: Chassaing et al. (2015). Some emulsifiers promote gut inflammation. Nature.

effects: High sugar and fat processed foods disturb sleep quality
Evening consumption delays melatonin production and reduces sleep depth
evidence: St-Onge et al. (2016). Processed food diets linked to poor sleep quality. Curr Opin Clin Nutr Metab Care.
